title: Golden Gate Capital to Buy Stake in Billing-Services Firm
summary: Bon Secours Mercy to receive $1.2 billion for controlling stake in Ensemble Health Partners. Bon Secours Mercy Health hospital system is selling a majority stake in its billing-software company to private-equity firm Golden Gate Capital in a deal that people familiar with the matter valued at roughly $1.2 billion-the latest transaction involving a health-care back-office technology firm.

title: Miami Executive Pleads Guilty in Venezuela Bribery Case
summary: José Manuel González Testino pleaded guilty to violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act in Petróleos de Venezuela SA probe. An executive admitted to bribing Petróleos de Venezuela SA officials to secure and keep lucrative contracts, the Justice Department said Wednesday.

title: Judge Bars New Jersey From Leaving Waterfront Watchdog
summary: State lawmakers passed legislation unilaterally withdrawing from commission. A federal judge blocked New Jersey's attempt to pull out of a bistate agency that polices organized crime along the region's waterfront.

title: Sign of the Sexist Apocalypse
summary: The United Nations finds that Siri and Alexa are tools of male oppression.. Perhaps you've read that robots will eventually rule over humanity, but in the meantime the United Nations has discovered a more pressing digital catastrophe. It seems Siri, the Apple voice assistant, is a tool of the patriarchy.

title: Robert Mueller's Parting Shot
summary: The special counsel gives House Democrats an impeachment nod.. Robert Mueller is an honorable man, as Marc Antony might have put it. And in his public statement Wednesday we saw a special counsel who went out of his way not to absolve Donald Trump and may have put his thumb on the scale toward impeachment.

title: Louisiana Legislature Approves Ban on Abortions After Six Weeks of Pregnancy
summary: Governor expected to sign 'heartbeat' bill, joining five other states this year. The Louisiana House passed a bill that would effectively outlaw abortions after six weeks of pregnancy, the latest in a wave of antiabortion legislation this year aimed at challenging U.S. Supreme Court protections for the procedure.

title: Connecticut's Public Health Bill Stalls on Industry Concerns
summary: Insurance carriers opposed bill that would have let individuals and small businesses buy policies through state. Legislation to create a public health-insurance option in Connecticut is off the table after an outcry from private insurers.

title: The FDIC's Mini Mea Culpa
summary: Being a federal regulator means never having to say you're sorry.. Through the bureaucratese, you can almost make out an apology. Last week the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation issued a letter acknowledging that "certain employees acted in a manner inconsistent with FDIC policies with respect to payday lenders." Namely, these regulators allegedly tried to cut off a legal industry's access to the banking system.

title: U.S. Says Russia Is Likely Defying Treaty Banning Nuclear Tests
summary: Intelligence assessment marks first time U.S. has said Kremlin failed to observe commitments under Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. Russia has likely been secretly carrying out nuclear tests with very low explosive power to help it upgrade its nuclear arsenal, according to a new U.S. intelligence assessment that challenges Moscow's claims that it is faithfully adhering to an international treaty banning nuclear tests.

title: The GOP's Duty: Explain the Cost of 'Free'
summary: Republicans can't outbid Santa Claus, but they can make the case for liberty and aspiration.. Progressives are changing the Democratic Party's focus from building stronger safety nets for the disadvantaged to subsidizing everything for everybody. Whereas Barack Obama once appeared radical for subsidizing health-care costs for the middle class as well as the poor, Democrats now promise free college, free health care and more-for everyone. Republicans can't outspend Democrats, but they can make the case for freedom and against the idea that everything is "free" without sounding like Scrooge.

title: High Interest Rates Are Hobbling Growth
summary: The Fed strengthened the dollar when U.S. growth and global stagnation were already boosting its value.. There's an increasingly strong case that the Federal Reserve should cut interest rates to weaken the U.S. dollar and encourage greater exports-and that it should do it soon.

title: The Growing Menace of the Moscow-Beijing-Tehran Axis
summary: The three powers have different goals, but each extracts advantage when others challenge the U.S.. Iran sabotages ships in the Persian Gulf and threatens to resume enrichment of uranium for its nuclear program. Russia dispatches troops to beleaguered dictator Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, while China sends logistical support. China resists a trade truce with the U.S. and seeks to drive a wedge between the U.S. and allies like Jordan and Saudi Arabia by selling them armed drones. Russia sends bombers and fighters into Alaska's Air Defense Identification Zone. Iran, Russia and China all work tirelessly to keep Syrian dictator Bashar Assad in power.

title: Socialists Don't Know History
summary: Young people don't remember the Soviet nightmare. But what's Sanders's excuse?. 'History repeats itself, first as tragedy, then as farce." I can't help but mumble this famous sentence from Karl Marx's "The Eighteenth Brumaire of Louis Bonaparte" whenever I hear about the socialist wing of the new-and distinctly not your father's-Democratic Party. Socialism caused the deaths of more than 100 million people under Lenin, Stalin and Mao, but young progressives want to give it another go.

title: Stacey Abrams Won't Go Away
summary: The loser of the Georgia governor's race builds a political career on failure.. Since losing the 2018 Georgia governor's race, Stacey Abrams has given self-pity a bad name. "I did win," Ms. Abrams still insists, making fantastic claims of a stolen election. She says Republican Gov. Brian Kemp holds the office only because "it was not a free and fair election." Never mind his 54,723-vote margin of victory; she's hoping that repeating a falsehood will make it true and pave her way to the governorship in 2022, if not the presidency in 2020.

title: 'The Shadow King' Review: Why Henry VI Was the Wrong Man for the Job
summary: As France balked and dynastic rivalry intensiﬁed, a gentle, pious man occupied the English throne. No one was less suited for medieval kingship.. 'Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown." Shakespeare gives this line to Henry IV, who was more fortunate than several other medieval English kings, for he died in his own bed of natural causes, and still king. In the list of monarchs from 1087 to 1485, four-William II, Edward II, Richard II and Henry VI-were almost certainly murdered, and the fate of the boy king Edward V (the elder of "the Princes in the Tower") remains a mystery. Of these uneasy rulers, it is Henry VI's story-enthrallingly told in "The Shadow King" by Lauren Johnson, a British historian-that is perhaps the saddest.

title: U.S. Fans Should Root for Toronto
summary: The Raptors may be Canadian, but they're a great American underdog story.. When the National Basketball Association finals begin Thursday, America should root for Canada's team. The Toronto Raptors-since 2001 the only team north of the border-are lovable underdogs, in the finals for the first time; the Golden State Warriors, a basketball Leviathan, are there for the fifth year in a row.

title: Bolton Accuses Iran in Ship Attacks

title: Budget Dysfunction Hurts Congress's Credibility
summary: Even if Congress had the will to address the government's mounting fiscal crisis, legislators no longer seem to know how. The original sin was the 2011 debt-ceiling confrontation, during which congressional Republicans ignored regular budget procedures and tried to wrench entitlement-spending restraints out of President Obama by threatening a breach of the government's debt ceiling.

title: Can I Wear Short Sleeves to Work Without Looking Like a Cubicle Dork?
summary: Half-sleeved dress shirts are often mocked for their off-putting associations, but some men have mastered the art of flashing some forearm. NASA'S APOLLO engineers were smart men and that's why they wore short-sleeved, white dress shirts through sweltering summers in places like Houston. Back in the 1960s, "I don't think everything was climate-controlled like it is now, so [short-sleeved shirts] just made a lot of practical sense," said David Hamilton, the co-owner of Hamilton Shirts, a 136-year-old shirtmaker based in Houston. For many men, that practicality trumps all, even with the prevalence of aggressive air-conditioning today in both offices and cars.

title: Classic Drive-In Restaurants Well Worth the Trip
summary: The Red Rooster in Brewster, N.Y., an all-American roadside burger joint, opened in the early 1960s and has, happily, evolved little since. Plus: 4 other delicious drive-ins around the country. IN 1963, after a falling out with his boss at the flagship Carvel ice-cream joint in Yonkers, German immigrant Heinz Tiede drove north on Route 22, the modest motorway that connects Manhattan to northern New York state. In Brewster, he happened upon a shuttered roadside business for sale. Over his wife's objections, he bought it and turned it into an essential stop for travelers. They couldn't miss it-a red-and-white-striped A-frame, its roof sprouting a giant plaster ice-cream cone filled with "soft-serve" and a few parking spots out front. Inside, cashiers shouted takeout orders to the cooks in the cramped kitchen, who cooked burgers on an electric grill while a Carpigiani machine swirled vanilla and chocolate into cake cones. Regulars knew to order a bacon cheeseburger with a fried egg on top, even though it wasn't on the cash-only menu. Outside, red metal picnic tables filled up with families, high-school sports teams after practice and weekenders. Miniature golf, with wooden obstacles, was added sometime in the 1970s and still sparks nostalgia like a Bob Seger song blasted from a car radio.

title: Inside Ulla Johnson's New Hamptons Outpost
summary: The ultra-feminine brand is opening a new brick-and-mortar store, its second ever, in the Hamptons this summer. Johnson tells WSJ. about her company's future. Designer Ulla Johnson might be a Brooklyn mom, dropping her kids off in clothes of her own design, but her personal style is that of a worldly au pair. Colorful, billowy-sleeved dresses, hand-embroidered blouses and voluminous skirts suggest the aesthetic of someone who's floated in from a faraway land-not a born-and-raised New Yorker, which she is. But the dreamy bohemian is a vibe she comes by honestly. The only child of two archaeologists, Johnson's early years included excursions to Iran, Germany and Croatia and other far-flung locales that have since informed the craftwork-focused aesthetic of her clothing.

title: The Music Executive Behind the Country-Rap Hit 'Old Town Road'
summary: The unconventional pairing of rapper Lil Nas X and Billy Ray Cyrus is the latest example of the genre-blurring, streaming-focused approach of Ron Perry, the 40-year-old head of Columbia Records. Behind the unlikely success of "Old Town Road"-the current hit song that combines hip-hop and country styles-is a 40-year-old executive whose savvy in building audiences on streaming-music services has made him a powerful force in the business.

title: Going From Big Fish to Small Fish: How Executives Can Deal With the Change
summary: Understanding the new company's culture and finding connections can help a leader's switch to a larger company from a smaller one. Andy Dunn has found it hard to work for Walmart Inc., the biggest retailer in the world, following its 2017 purchase of Bonobos, a small men's clothing retailer that he co-founded and led for years.

title: German Unemployment Rises for the First Time in Five Years
summary: Economic slowdown threatens decadelong jobs boom, raising pressure on shaky government. Germany's jobless rate climbed unexpectedly in May, the first increase in more than five years, in a sign that a recent slowdown in growth is spreading further through Europe's largest economy.

title: Technology Drives Deals Because No One Wants to Be the Next Blockbuster Video
summary: Some companies are buying up everything in sight in hopes of finding a tech wunderkind like Netflix. Others are combining with rivals to answer tech puzzles that have yet to be solved.. The last of the 9,000 Blockbuster Video stores that once roamed the Earth sits at 211 NE Revere Ave. in Bend, Ore., a strip-mall storefront trapped in amber right down to dot-matrix printers and computers booted up with floppy disks.

title: U.K.'s Boris Johnson to Appear in Court Over Brexit Claims
summary: Former foreign secretary's lawyers say the case was 'brought for political purposes' to undermine the Brexit result. LONDON-U.K. lawmaker Boris Johnson, the leading candidate to become Britain's next prime minister, has been ordered to appear in court over allegations of misconduct in office relating to claims he made around the Brexit referendum.

title: DowDuPont to Take Goodwill Charge of $800 Million to $1.3 Billion
summary: Impairment charge reflects slowed demand in the biomaterials business unit and challenging conditions in U.S. bioethanol market. DowDuPont Inc. expects to record impairment charges of $800 million to $1.3 billion primarily due to goodwill in its current quarter ending June 30.

title: Stocks to Watch: Bed Bath & Beyond, Dick's Sporting, CSX
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Wednesday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Wednesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: Businesses Balk at Bid to Block Robocalls
summary: Debt collectors, credit unions among those lobbying the FCC to reconsider its call-blocking proposal. Some businesses are pushing back against a regulatory proposal that would allow phone companies to block unwanted robocalls.

title: Prospect of Tighter Money at the ECB Increases
summary: Negotiations for top European Union jobs point to higher chances of a hawkish tilt in central-bank policy. The battle for the European Union's top jobs has begun. If the first skirmishes are any guide, the next president of the European Central Bank may be less happy to bail out investors in any future crisis.

title: The Star Wars Theme Parks: Five Key Facts to Know
summary: A visitor's guide to the intergalactic experiences at the Star Wars theme parks, opening in May at Disneyland and in August at Walt Disney World. The size of Star Wars: Galaxy's Edge in each park-the largest single-themed expansions in Disney Parks history.

title: Lasers Aimed at Australian Navy Pilots in South China Sea
summary: Beams came from fishing boats, officials say; the U.S. has blamed similar incidents on China's military or its maritime militia of fishermen. SYDNEY-Fishing boats in Chinese-claimed waters in the South China Sea shone lasers at the pilots of Australian navy combat helicopters during a recent exercise, Australian officials said, which follows similar incidents targeting U.S. military aircraft in the western Pacific and Indian oceans.

title: Citing Poor Health, Modi Aide Won't Join Next Indian Cabinet
summary: Finance minister had been strong defender of the government's economic policies. NEW DELHI-India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley, one of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's closest aides, has asked to be left out of the country's next cabinet, citing health issues.

title: Fortune to Add Paywall in Bid to Diversify Revenue Stream
summary: With print advertising in decline, magazine also plans to raise cover price and offer more conferences. Fortune magazine is raising its cover price, launching a digital paywall and boosting its conference business, in its first decisive steps as an independent publisher.

title: California Draws Wave of Democratic Contenders
summary: Party's largest gathering so far of 2020 presidential candidates is coming to San Francisco convention. LOS ANGELES-After years of deferring to smaller states, the biggest and most complicated prize on the presidential primary calendar is poised to get a lot more attention from Democratic presidential contenders.

title: Investors Beware: Consumers' Story Isn't Yours
summary: A rising stock market fed into investors' belief that retailers were having a great quarter, but back in reality, things were different. Just because you are feeling good doesn't mean everyone else is. When it comes to consumers, investors may have lost sight of that simple truth.

title: Are Stocks as Expensive as Shiller's Measure Says?
summary: A valuation tool popularized by Robert Shiller is affected by corporate losses that occurred more than a decade ago. The sharp losses companies experienced following the 2008 financial crisis are now a distant memory, yet they cause ripples. A widely cited stock-market-valuation measure popularized by Nobel Prize-winning economist Robert Shiller looks different as a result. Perhaps it shouldn't.

title: Venezuela's Military Deserters Face Disappointment Across the Border
summary: Some soldiers had hoped to launch an incursion into their home country but now appear to be stuck in Colombia. CÚCUTA, Colombia-When Gabriel Pérez fled for this Colombian border city after defecting from Venezuela's military, he thought he and hundreds of other military deserters would soon launch an incursion to topple the autocrat back home.

title: Lawmakers Push for More Security at Houses of Worship
summary: Legislation in Senate would increase grant money for measures such as surveillance cameras, active-shooter training. Local, state and federal lawmakers are pushing for funding to protect houses of worship following a series of deadly shootings, signaling that the days of the church with its doors propped open at all hours may be over.

title: Europe's Green Parties Grow New Support
summary: Environment-focused parties emerge as fourth-largest bloc in European Parliament following last week's elections. Europe's Greens are back.

title: Female Hedge-Fund Veteran Has Contemplated Comeback
summary: Anne Dias managed money from billionaire Julian Robertson and her then-husband, Ken Griffin. Anne Dias, once one of the few women to run her own hedge fund, has been considering a return to money management.

title: Many Teens Check Their Phones in Middle of Night
summary: Survey finds parents do the same thing; sleep expert calls the trend troubling. Teenagers are so attached to their smartphones that more than a third of them wake up in the middle of the night and check the devices, according to a new survey.

title: A Good Night's Sleep in the Sky? In Your Dreams
summary: Airlines know how important shut-eye is to fliers, yet some new updates in business class overlook what they need most. Sleeping on airplanes is hard enough in business class. It's darn near impossible for most in coach. But new research is yielding tips on how to give yourself a snoring chance.

title: U.S.-China Tech Tensions Help Push Alibaba Toward Hong Kong
summary: The New York-listed company is wise to diversify its funding sources as Chinese companies come under intensifying scrutiny in Washington. Alibaba Group Holding 's plan to list closer to home has been simmering for some time, but the escalating U.S.-China trade conflict could finally bring it to a boil.

title: Real Winners From Trump's Tariffs Are China's Neighbors
summary: Preliminary evidence suggests that extra U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods are a cost to both countries. Who really pays the cost of President Trump's new tariffs on China?

title: Australia's Wobbly Growth Streak Has Some Seeing Easy Money on the Way
summary: Investors already expect as many as three cuts in the official cash rate, but that might not be enough to achieve the central bank's goals. SYDNEY-Australia's bond yields have hit record lows, part of a global swoon, as investors wager it could be the next rich economy forced to adopt unorthodox monetary policy.

title: Tornadoes Leave Trail of Destruction in Ohio
summary: Storms down trees, damage homes across Dayton; at least one person killed. Powerful tornadoes swept through Ohio Monday night, leaving a path of destruction in Dayton and at least one person dead in a small city to the north, officials said.

title: Renault Deal Is Put to Test in France
summary: Fiat Chrysler's merger offer stirs criticism as potential threat to jobs and symbol of national industry. PARIS-Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV's proposal to merge with Renault SA is under scrutiny in France, where the government, unions and some executives at the French auto maker are questioning whether the plan undervalues Renault and puts jobs at risk.

title: City Councilman Pushes Easier Access to Country's Largest Public Cemetery
summary: Hart Island's potter's field, run by city's Department of Correction, holds more than 1 million remains. New York City's potter's field, which holds the remains of more than 1 million people, could become more accessible to the public with two bills being introduced Thursday in the City Council.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Kamala Harris Proposes Abortion Law Modeled on Voting Rights Act
summary: The Democratic presidential hopeful wants the Justice Department to review state laws restricting abortion before they would take effect. States looking to change abortion laws would have to meet requirements modeled on the 1965 Voting Rights Act under a new proposal from Sen. Kamala Harris's campaign, the latest effort by a Democratic presidential contender to address an increasingly high-profile campaign issue.

title: Huawei Seeks Quick Overturn of Law Restricting Its U.S. Business
summary: 'Politicians in the U.S. are using the strength of an entire nation to come after a private company,' company says. Huawei Technologies Co. asked a judge to quickly rule in its favor in its legal challenge to overturn a law that restricts its business in the U.S., saying American officials have failed to provide evidence that the Chinese tech giant poses a security threat.

title: Trade Fight, Curbs on Huawei Threaten 5G Growth in U.S.
summary: Potential impact on carriers, consumers shows how globally entwined the internet and telecom sectors are. The Trump administration's offensives aimed at frustrating the 5G ambitions of China and mobile-technology giant Huawei Technologies Co. threaten to impede America's wireless ambitions, too.

title: Venezuela's Central Bank Releases Data on Dire Economy
summary: The government's economic statistics, usually a closely guarded secret, show the country's inflation as the highest in the world. Venezuela's economy contracted 19.2% in the first nine months of 2018 from the year-earlier period, as private consumption fell sharply and inflation soared in the crisis-racked nation, according to the Central Bank of Venezuela.

title: McConnell Says Senate Would Seek to Confirm a Supreme Court Nominee in 2020
summary: Reverses stance from 2016, when he refused to hold hearings on Obama court pick, citing election year. WASHINGTON-Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell made clear Tuesday that he would seek to confirm any nomination by President Trump to fill a Supreme Court seat that might open up next year, despite having blocked former President Obama's high-court pick during an election year.

title: Steel Executive Seized in Spain in Mexican Corruption Case Tied to Pemex
summary: Arrest warrant is also said to be issued for former chief of state oil company. MEXICO CITY-Spanish police arrested the chairman of a leading Mexican steelmaker on Tuesday as part of a widening probe into alleged bribery linked to the sale of a fertilizer plant by the steel firm to state-run oil giant Petróleos Mexicanos.

title: REITs Bet Big on the Mortgage Market
summary: These investors have become a key source of capital as government's role in the market shrinks. Investment trusts that buy residential home loans are piling into mortgage bonds, taking on a more prominent role in the housing market as the government retreats.

title: New York City's Bail Overhaul Aims to Keep Teens Out of Jail
summary: They would be placed in the city's Supervised Release Program with supervision, access to voluntary services and therapy. More teens accused of serious felonies will be released from jail without bail under New York City's latest push to limit incarceration, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Tuesday.
